DOC.HEAD: China Faces Growing Demand for Imported Wheat
DOC.TEXT: China is the world's largest wheat producer but is not keeping pace with its own consumer demand for more bread, noodles and dumplings. As a result, China has been buying huge amounts of wheat from other countries, including the United States. An Agriculture Department analyst says import demand will continue to grow, at least through the turn of the century. ``Even though it is the world's largest producer of wheat, China's domestic demand exceeds supplies,'' says Frederick W. Crook of the department's Economic Research Service. ``Wheat output has risen steadily as farmers have boosted yields because of greater irrigation and use of improved varieties.'' Crook, in a report on China's wheat economy, said population growth and ``consumer preference for wheat products'' such as noodles, steamed dumplings, bread and pastries have spurred demand. As the world's most populous country with 1.1 billion people, even slight changes in per capita use can translate into large numbers. Crook said per capita wheat consumption rose steadily from 29 kilograms in 1960 to 48 kilos in 1978. Then, as supplies increased because of import and production gains, the average jumped to 90 kilograms per person in 1987. A kilogram is about 2.2 pounds. Ninety kilos would be about 198 pounds, or approximately 3.3 bushels of wheat, allowing 60 pounds per bushel. China has been at peaks and valleys as a customer of U.S. wheat farmers since the early 1970s. Lately, Beijing has been a large and consistent buyer of U.S. wheat, rivaling the Soviet Union at times. In the 1988-89 wheat marketing year that ran through last May 31, China imported almost 8.1 million metric tons of U.S. wheat and became the largest foreign customer of American growers. The Soviet Union, by comparison, imported 4.96 million tons in the same period. So far in 1989-90, China has bought about 4.7 million tons against the Soviet Union's purchases as of Dec. 14 of less than 2 million tons. A metric ton, the unit favored in world grain trade, is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 36.7 bushels of wheat. It also is equal to 1,000 kilograms. Both China and the Soviet Union have bought large amounts of wheat under a U.S. price subsidy arrangement, the Export Enhancement Program. Under EEP, private exporters can sell to designated foreign countries at reduced prices and then collect USDA-owned commodities as ``bonuses'' or subsidies to make up the price difference. From a production standpoint, China has been the world's largest wheat producer in four of the last five years, according to USDA statistics. China's wheat output this year, for example, is estimated at 91 million tons, compared with 89 million for the Soviet Union and 55.6 million for the United States. Other major producers this year include: Canada, 24.4 million tons; Australia, 12.5 million; Argentina, 10.7 million; India, 53 million; Eastern Europe, 42.3 million; and the European Economic Community, 79.3 million. Crook said that by world standards China has achieved ``fairly high wheat yields'' and is surpassing those in India, Pakistan and countries which have large areas of non-irrigated wheat, such as Canada, Australia, the Soviet Union and the United States. On the other hand, Crook said wheat yields are higher in Mexico, France, Poland and Japan. Crook said that Chinese experts predict wheat yields will climb an average of about 1.65 percent a year and that by the year 2000 there will be some decrease in total wheat area. But they claim that total output by then will increase to between 100 million and 105 million tons. ``China's population will continue to grow in the next decade, and if per capita income continues to rise, demand for wheat will also increase,'' Crook said. ``However, prospects for rapid gains in domestic wheat output are dim because little arable (land) can be shifted to wheat production, and yields are already high.'' As a result, he added, the outlook for wheat exports to China ``looks promising in the near future.'' But the rate of growth will depend mostly on the ability of the rest of China's economy to earn foreign exchange.
